lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’„­ ğ’Š ğ’Œ“ ğ’ˆ¦ğ’„˜ğ’ƒ¼ ğ’Œ“ğ’º ğ’€€

transliterations.simplified: nin me Å¡ara u dalla ea

lines.translation: Lady of all me, resplendent daylight
lines.explanation: The first two words of the poem, nin and me, are both keywords that play a crucial role throughout the text. The word nin, 'lady,' recurs at regular frequencies, mostly to open or close a section of the poem. Note that Å¡ar2, 'all,' can also mean 'countless.' One manuscript renders the line as: 'lady of sweet (du10) me'; this is likely due to a graphic confusion of the two signs Å¡ar2 and du10, which look almost identical.

transliterations.transliteration: munus zi me-lam2 gur3-ru ki-aÄ2 an uraÅ¡-a
transliterations.word_by_word: woman true terrifying_light carry-that beloved An Urash-of
transliterations.simplified: munus zi melam guru kiaÄ An UraÅ¡a

lines.translation: Righteous woman, laden with a terrifying light, loved by An and Urash
lines.explanation: An and Urash are the deified forms of heaven and earth, respectively. The me-lam2 is the awe-inducing halo of light that surrounds gods and other supernatural beings. Zgoll (301â€“302) notes that the signs munus zi, 'righteous woman,' also form an archaic spelling of the word zirru, which was one of Enheduanaâ€™s titles as high priestess. The writing of the word zirru had since changed into nunuz-zi, but it is possible that the older form lingered in the background, instilling a connection between Inana and Enheduana herself.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆªğ’‰­ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’Š‘ ğ’†Ÿ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’†·
lines.translation: nugig of An, she of the great jewels
lines.explanation: The nugig was originally a designation for a wetnurse or midwife, often of high status and sometimes affiliated with a temple. It is used as an epithet for Inana and other goddesses, but its meaning was confused already in antiquity: for the history of the term, see Brisch. The reading of the signs MUÅ 3 KEÅ 2 is unclear. Zgoll, Foster, and Black et al. take it to mean 'pectoral jewels,' an emblem of power worn on the breast. Attinger understands it as 'bound' (keÅ¡e2) 'coronets' (suh10): the phrase would then mean 'she to whom the great coronets are bound,' that is, 'she who holds the great coronets.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚‡ ğ’£ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’†  ğ’‰˜ ğ’‰† ğ’‚— ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’º ğ’ˆ
lines.translation: she who loves the righteous crown, who is suitable for en-ship
lines.explanation: The en-ship can refer to the position of either a political ruler or a high priestessâ€”en can mean both. The second part of the line is here taken to describe Inana, but it could also describe the crown, as in: 'She who loves the righteous crown that befits the high priestess.' The ambiguity may be intentional, again implying a connection between Inana and Enheduana herself, who was the en of Nanna.

lines.translation: who has taken hold of its seven me
lines.explanation: The number 'seven' is not necessarily to be taken literally: it hints at Inanaâ€™s many me (which, as noted in line 1, are innumerable), but also signposts the poetic structure of the following section, which consists of stanzas of seven lines, introduced by the phrase nin-Äu10, 'my lady.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’†· ğ’Š• ğ’†Ÿ ğ’‰ ğ’ ğ’‚Š ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: My lady! Of the great me, you are their guardian
lines.explanation: This is the first appearance of the phrase nin-Äu10, 'my lady,' which in this section introduces a new stanza.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‚Š ğ’… ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‹— ğ’ª ğ’‚  ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‚Š ğ’‡²

transliterations.simplified: me mueil me Å¡uzuÅ¡e me muela

lines.translation: You have lifted the me, you have hung the me from your hand
lines.explanation: Here as elsewhere, the me are depicted as physical objects, hanging from Inanaâ€™s hand perhaps like beads on a string.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‚Š ğ’Œ´ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ƒ® ğ’ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‹°

transliterations.simplified: me mueur me gabaza me bitab

lines.translation: You have gathered the me, you have clutched the me to your breast
lines.explanation: This heavily patterned couplet (meâ€“verbâ€“meâ€“body partâ€“verb) is also structured by a heavy alliteration on m-, with all but the last verb beginning with mu-.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ƒ²ğ’” ğ’¶ ğ’†³ ğ’Š ğ’…œ ğ’€ ğ’‚Š ğ’‹§
lines.translation: Like an uÅ¡umgal, you have deposited venom on the foreign land
lines.explanation: The uÅ¡umgal, often translated 'basilisk' or 'dragon,' is a giant horned serpent with fangs and (evidently) a venomous spit. A relief depicting a similar creature, the muÅ¡huÅ¡Å¡u, gives us an idea of what they were thought to look like.

transliterations.simplified: IÅ¡kurgin ki Å¡e giaza AÅ¡nan labaÅ¡iÄal

lines.translation: like Ishkur, where you shout, Ashnan disappears before you
lines.explanation: Ishkur is the god of storms and Ashnan the goddess of grain. The line compares Inanaâ€™s howl to a storm that flattens the farmland, by either bending the grain stalks or wrenching them from the ground.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š’ ğ’†³ ğ’‰ ğ’‹« ğ’‡¯ğ’º ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: Flood that streams down from these mountains
lines.explanation: Since kur can also mean 'foreign land,' the line may refer to Inana as a destructive force descending upon the enemy, but the preposition -ta, 'from,' makes it more likely that mountains are meant.

lines.translation: supreme in heaven and earth: you are their Inana
lines.explanation: The ending of the line is striking, especially since Inana is almost never referred to by name in this poem. Various interpretations are possible. The word Inana could also mean 'goddess' in general, leading to translations such as 'you are their goddess.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’Š ğ’Œ¦ ğ’‚Š ğ’€€ğ’€­ ğ’‚·
lines.translation: Blazing fire raining on the land!
lines.explanation: In this section, every seventh line begins with nin-Äu10, â€œmy lady,â€ except this line, where the expected phrase is replaced by another kind of repetition: the threefold repetition of the cuneiform sign ne.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’‰Œ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‹§ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’Œ¨ ğ’Š ğ’„·ğ’‹› ğ’€€

transliterations.transliteration: an-ne2 me Å¡um2-ma nin ur-ra u5-a
transliterations.word_by_word: An me give-that lady beast-on ride-that
transliterations.simplified: Ane me Å¡uma nin ura ua

lines.translation: She to whom An gave the me, lady riding on lions,
lines.explanation: Here, in l. 128 below, and in l. 23 of the Hymn, the word ur, which generally means 'beast' or 'dog,' seems to refer to lions, which is the animal most often associated with Inana. Note also the play on sounds at the end of the line: ura ua.

lines.translation: who, by the holy order of An, gives orders.
lines.explanation: The syntactical structure of the line is difficultâ€”see the discussion in Attingerâ€”but however one understands the grammar, it must refer to An empowering Inana to give orders. As in l. 13, the same cuneiform sign, here ka, is used three times in a row, representing different sounds.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰ºğ’€­ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’†· ğ’ƒ» ğ’ª ğ’€€ ğ’€ ğ’€€ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’ª
lines.translation: Who can understand the great rites that are your possession?
lines.explanation: Much as with the me, the 'rites' mentioned in this line are best understood as activities that must be performed over and over again to keep the cosmos aright: other possible translations of biluda include 'duties' and 'ordinances.' The line thus makes the point that Inana plays a crucial, but unfathomable role in maintaining the world orderâ€”including the destruction of enemy lands. Note also the play on the syllable zu, which means first 'your' and then 'to know' (another play on the same syllable comes in l. 27).

lines.translation: Destroyer of mountains, you give force to the storm.
lines.explanation: This couplet is tightly constructed. In the previous line, the second word was gal-gal, 'great'; here, it is gul-gul, 'to destroy.' In the previous line, the second-to-last word was aba,'who'; here, that same sound is split into two words, a2, 'force,' and the prefix baâ€“ in 'you give.' Note that the description of Inana as 'destroyer of mountains' alludes to the myth of Inana and Ebih.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†  ğ’‰˜ ğ’€­ ğ’‚— ğ’†¤ ğ’‡² ğ’Œ¦ ğ’ˆ  ğ’‰ ğ’ˆª ğ’…” ğ’Š‘
lines.translation: Beloved by Enlil, you impose fear on the land.
lines.explanation: Beside 'impose,' ri can also mean 'to inject' or 'to pour.'

lines.translation: At the command of Enlil, you stand ready.
lines.explanation: Note the symmetry with the previous line: both begin with the sequence word-deity-of, and both have aÄ2as their second sign.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ ğ’‰º ğ’‰˜ ğ’ª ğ’‚  ğ’†³ ğ’‰Œ ğ’ƒµğ’ƒµ ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: My lady! The enemy land bends at your battle cry.
lines.explanation: A new section is introduced by the repetition of nin-Äu10.

lines.translation: When humanity, (fleeing) from fear, terrifying light, and storms
lines.explanation: Note the play on u18-lu, which means 'storm,' but which also forms part of the word 'humanity.' The u18-lu is in some texts identified as the south wind, which in southern Iraq was a sandstorm blowing in from the Arabian desert.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ƒ» ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ƒ» ğ’„Š ğ’‰ ğ’…‡ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š‘ ğ’º
lines.translation: stood before you in silence,
lines.explanation: This is the third line in a row to start with the sound ni; note also the similarity with the previous line: ni-me vs. niÄme. The expression Äiri_gub, 'to walk the foot,' is unclear: it might mean 'to walk' or 'to stand in attendance.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‹« ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’„­ğ’„Š ğ’‰ ğ’‹— ğ’€ ğ’‚Š ğ’Š‘ ğ’‹¾
lines.translation: you took the most terrifying of the me:
lines.explanation: That is, Inana takes the most horrific of the cosmic duties upon herself.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„¿ ğ’¾ ğ’€€ğ’…† ğ’Š ğ’†¤ ğ’…… ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’‹º
lines.translation: the threshold of tears is opened for you.
lines.explanation: This and the following two lines end with verbs that include the prefix -ra-, 'for you,' in a subtle form of epistrophe (the repetition of a word at the end of the line).

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚ ğ’€€ ğ’‰ª ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’†· ğ’‹» ğ’€ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š‘ ğ’º
lines.translation: they walk on the road to the house of great grief for you,
lines.explanation: Because of the verbal tense, Zgoll argues that the previous two lines should be read as an interjected clause, and that the sentence beginning in l. 21 ends here.

lines.translation: before battle, (their) possessions are sacked for you.
lines.explanation: By Inanaâ€™s power, the grieving people are made to surrender all that they own without putting up a fight.

lines.translation: My lady! The strength you have can eat through teeth.?
lines.explanation: A new section is introduced by the repetition of nin-Äu10. This is a difficult line, and the ancient scribes were clearly confused about it.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œ“ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’¶ ğ’‰Œ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: You charge like the charging storm,
lines.explanation: The reduplication of the verbal root (du7-du7) in Sumerian indicates an ongoing movement, and this redoubling is used for full aural effect in this and the following three lines.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œ“ ğ’…— ğ’Š ğ’Š ğ’• ğ’…— ğ’… ğ’• ğ’€Š ğ’Š ğ’Š ğ’€­
lines.translation: you roar with the roaring storm,
lines.explanation: The line continues the doubled doubling introduced in the previous line, here of ra-ra.

lines.translation: you shout with Ishkur.
lines.explanation: The formulation recalls l. 10, where Inanaâ€™s shout (Å¡e27_gi4) is also compared to Ishkur, the storm god.

lines.translation: You exhaust yourself with each hurricane,
lines.explanation: The theme of redoubling is marvelously continued here. The reduplication of a noun in Sumerian makes it plural, often a comprehensive plural.

lines.translation: but your feet are filled with tirelessness.
lines.explanation: That is, even as she tires herself out, Inana is endlessly refreshed.

lines.translation: With a harp of grief, they perform the lamentation.
lines.explanation: The balaÄ was a musical instrument used to accompany ritual lamentations.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’€­ ğ’€€ ğ’‰£ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: My lady! The Anuna, the great gods,
lines.explanation: A new section is again introduced by the repetition of nin-Äu10. The Anuna are the highest circle of gods in the Sumerian pantheon.

lines.translation: flying like bats, flutter to the ruin mounds because of you,
lines.explanation: The word braÅ¡, translated here as 'flutter,' is very rare: it is a loanword from Akkadian napruÅ¡u that became an unusual construction in Sumerian.

lines.translation: as they could not withstand your terrifying gaze.
lines.explanation: This line begins a set of three symmetrical units, all focused on Inanaâ€™s wrath.

lines.translation: No one can oppose your terrifying visage.
lines.explanation: The line has a play on the syllable saÄ, which begins the two halves of the line: first as a part of the word for 'face,' then of the word 'oppose.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š® ğ’Œˆ ğ’€ ğ’ ğ’€€ ğ’€ ğ’€€ ğ’Œˆ ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚— ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: Your angry heartâ€”who can soothe it?
lines.explanation: The heart was generally thought to be the seat of the mood and mind, and since an angry heart was a hot heart, to 'cool' someoneâ€™s heart was to calm them.

lines.translation: Your wicked heartâ€”to soothe it is overwhelming.
lines.explanation: Enheduana again refers to her task (praising and soothing Inana) as mah, 'mighty' or 'overwhelming,' in l. 64.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’„¯ ğ’‰Œ ğ’Š· ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’Š® ğ’‰Œ ğ’„¾

transliterations.transliteration: nin ur5 i3-sa6 nin Å¡a3 i3-hul2
transliterations.word_by_word: lady liver sweeten lady heart please
transliterations.simplified: nin ur isa nin Å¡a ihul

lines.translation: Lady, will this mood be sweetened? Lady, will this heart be pleased?
lines.explanation: The symmetries of the previous lines culminate in this highly compact line, which also rounds off the opening section.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œˆ ğ’€ ğ’‰¡ ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚— ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚— ğ’Œ‰ ğ’ƒ² ğ’€­ ğ’‚—ğ’ª ğ’ˆ¾
lines.translation: Your anger cannot be cooled, great daughter of Suen.
lines.explanation: Suen is an alternative name for Nanna. The new section is marked by a chiasm, consisting of an opening couplet, the destruction of a mountain, the destruction of a city, and a repetition of the initial couplet.

transliterations.transliteration: nin kur-ra diri-ga a-ba-a ki-za ba-an-tum3
transliterations.word_by_word: lady land-to exceed-that who place-your-from take
transliterations.simplified: nin kura diriga aba kiza bantum

lines.translation: Lady, greater than the land, who can take away from your dominion?
lines.explanation: The line uses the word ki, 'place,' in an unusual metaphorical sense, translated here as 'dominion.' Zgoll also notes the question could equally be translated 'who can escape your dominion?'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„¯ ğ’Š• ğ’†  ğ’ ğ’€ ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ ğ’ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’€­ ğ’Šºğ’Šºğ’‰ª ğ’ƒ» ğ’ˆªğ’‰­ ğ’‰
lines.translation: You extended? your dominion over the mountain: Ashnan cannot be found there,
lines.explanation: The destruction of the mountain recalls the myth of Inana and Ebih, and Ashnan is used to refer metonymically to grain and the harvest.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†ğ’ƒ² ğ’€€ ğ’€ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‚Š ğ’Š‘ ğ’Š‘
lines.translation: its city gates were set on fire.
lines.explanation: Literally, 'fire was put on its city gates.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€€ğ’‡‰ ğ’€ ğ’Œ€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€­ ğ’Œ¤ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’‰ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’…˜ ğ’…˜
lines.translation: Because of you, blood flows in its canals; because of you, its people drink it.
lines.explanation: Two manuscripts have instead 'the people cannot drink,' drawing a different but equally painful consequence from the water having turned to blood.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†  ğ’‹¢ ğ’‡» ğ’‚  ğ’ƒ» ğ’‰ ğ’‰ ğ’‰ ğ’€€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’ºğ’º ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: Its army, all together, is brought to you,
lines.explanation: Zgoll notes that ni2-bi-a, normally 'together,' can also be read 'in their fear' (both here and in the following lines); the ambiguity could easily be intentional.

lines.translation: its elite troops, all together, are disbanded for you,
lines.explanation: The word translated as 'elite troops' literally means 'the bound ones' (perhaps indicating professional soldiers as opposed to conscripts), which makes for an ironic fate: the bound are unbound.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„¨ ğ’€‰ ğ’Œ‡ ğ’‰ ğ’‰ ğ’‰ ğ’€€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’» ğ’„€ ğ’Œ
lines.translation: its strong men, all together, are presented to you.
lines.explanation: The word ÄuruÅ¡ specifically means 'able-bodied man,' primarily meaning young men.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œ· ğ’€ ğ’†  ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ ğ’² ğ’€ ğ’‚‡ ğ’„¿ ğ’Œˆ ğ’‹›
lines.translation: Its cityâ€™s place of play is filled up by the storm,
lines.explanation: The ki-e-ne-di or 'place of merriment' was presumably a locale for dancing and drinking.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„¨ ğ’Š® ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’‰ ğ’ˆ‚ ğ’‚  ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’Š¬ ğ’Š‘ ğ’Œ
lines.translation: its best men, captive, are driven before you.
lines.explanation: It is uncertain how to transliterate the word rendered here as heÅ¡e5-eÅ¡2â€”other possibilities include lu2Å¡e3 and heÅ¡e5Å¡e3, but the meaning is clear enough: 'prisoner,' 'chained,' or the like.

lines.translation: To the city that did not say, 'The country belongs to you,'
lines.explanation: The text turns from the mountain to the city. Some manuscripts display a different understanding of this line: 'the enemy (kur2) city that did not say, â€˜(we belong) to you.â€™'

lines.translation: that did not say, 'To your father,'
lines.explanation: The line literally reads, 'your birth father.' While unusual in English, the specification of Nanna as Inanaâ€™s birth father, or 'your father who bore you,' is conventional in Sumerian.

transliterations.transliteration: inim ku3-zu bi2-in-du11 ki Äiri3-zu he2-eb-gi4
transliterations.word_by_word: word holy-your speak place foot-your return
transliterations.simplified: inim kuzu bindu ki Äirizu hebgi

lines.translation: your holy order was spoken: the place returned to your feet.
lines.explanation: This line concludes a fourfold repetition of the structure nounâ€“nounâ€“'your' (zu and za).

lines.translation: Its womb is disturbed,?
lines.explanation: The reading and translation are debated, but Attinger's interpretation of 'womb' and 'slip' is followed here.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š© ğ’‰ ğ’® ğ’€€ ğ’‰Œ ğ’‹« ğ’Š· ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’• ğ’€Š ğ’‰
lines.translation: its woman does not speak sweet words with her spouse,
lines.explanation: The line implies a connection between eloquence and eroticism, leading to the next line.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ˆª ğ’…‡ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€œ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’• ğ’€Š ğ’„„ ğ’„„
lines.translation: at nighttime she does not consult with him,
lines.explanation: This line will be echoed later in the text, in l. 140.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ƒ» ğ’†¬ ğ’Š® ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’‰† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’• ğ’€­ ğ’” ğ’Š‘
lines.translation: she does not show him the pure things within her.
lines.explanation: The word Å¡a3, 'heart' or 'inside,' and ku3, 'pure' or 'shining,' imply a deeper meaning related to emotions and inner beauty.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’…‡ ğ’„¢ ğ’£ ğ’£ ğ’„¿ ğ’Œ‰ ğ’ƒ² ğ’€­ ğ’‚—ğ’ª ğ’ˆ¾
lines.translation: Rearing aurochs, great daughter of Suen.
lines.explanation: The aurochs is a now extinct breed of wild oxen, larger than domesticated cattle.

transliterations.transliteration: nin an-ra diri-ga a-ba-a ki-za ba-an-tum3
transliterations.word_by_word: lady heaven-to exceed-that who place-your-from take
transliterations.simplified: nin anra diriga aba kiza bantum

lines.translation: Lady, greater than heaven, who can take away from your dominion?
lines.explanation: In this line, Inana is said to exceed the skies, an, symmetrically complementing her earlier association with the earth.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’£ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ƒ² ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: Great lady of ladies, who, for the righteous me,
lines.explanation: The next sectionâ€”an autobiographical passage in which Enheduana introduces herselfâ€”is again introduced by two of the keywords of the poem, nin and me. The text could also mean that Inana was born according to, not for, the 'righteous me,' since the me were also seen as the underlying patterns that regulate events.

transliterations.transliteration: Å¡a3 ku3-ta e3-a ama ugu-ni-ir diri-ga
transliterations.word_by_word: heart holy-from come_forth mother bear-her-to exceed-that
transliterations.simplified: Å¡a kuta ea ama ugunir diriga

lines.translation: was born from a holy womb, who surpasses her own mother!
lines.explanation: Note the repetition of the words Å¡a3 and ku3, which were also juxtaposed in l. 57. The self-referential announcement of the song which comes in l. 63â€“65 is immediately preceded by the theme of birth, especially given that Enheduana will (arguably) later describe herself as 'giving birth' to the poem.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ƒ² ğ’ª ğ’…† ğ’…… ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’†³ ğ’†³ ğ’Š
lines.translation: Clever and prescient lady of the lands,
lines.explanation: The translation of igi-Äal2 as 'prescient,' specifically (as opposed to the more general 'wise') follows Zgoll.

transliterations.transliteration: zi-Äal2 uÄ3 lu-a Å¡ir3 ku3-zu ga-am3-du11
transliterations.word_by_word: living people numerous-of song holy-your speak
transliterations.simplified: ziÄal uÄ lua Å¡ir kuzu gamdu

lines.translation: of living beings and countless peopleâ€”I will sing your holy song!
lines.explanation: Here, the 'I' of the poem first appears as an active subject, and the text refers to itself as the narrator announces that she will sing a hymn to Inana.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’£ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’€€ ğ’º ğ’ˆ  ğ’ƒ² ğ’‰ ğ’…— ğ’‚µ ğ’ª ğ’ˆ¤ ğ’€€ğ’€­

transliterations.transliteration: diÄir zi me-a tum2-ma gal-bi du11-ga-zu mah-am3
transliterations.word_by_word: god righteous me-in bring-that greatly speak-that-your mighty-is
transliterations.simplified: diÄir zi mea tuma galbi dugazu maham

lines.translation: Righteous goddess, to whom the me are brought, it is overwhelming to exalt you.
lines.explanation: As in l. 39, Enheduana refers to the task she has set herselfâ€”praising and soothing Inanaâ€”as mah, 'mighty' or 'overwhelming.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š® ğ’‹¤ ğ’º ğ’Š© ğ’£ ğ’Š® ğ’Œ“ğ’Œ“ ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’ª ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’…—

transliterations.transliteration: Å¡a3 su3-ra2 munus zi Å¡a3 dadag-ga me-zu ga-mu-ra-ab-du11
transliterations.word_by_word: heart distant woman righteous heart shining me-your speak
transliterations.simplified: Å¡a sura munus zi Å¡a dadaga mezu gamurabdu

lines.translation: Distant heart, righteous woman, shining heart! I will sing of your me.
lines.explanation: This is a clear instance of self-reference, since this poem is a song about the me. To have a 'distant heart' means to be inscrutable, a common description of the godsâ€™ minds in Sumerian and Akkadian literature.

lines.translation: For you, I entered the holy Äipar.
lines.explanation: The Äipar was the residence of high priestesses within the temple complex. This line marks a turning point in the poem, where the narrator (Enheduana) reveals her identity.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚— ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‚— ğ’‚— ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: I am the high priestess, I am Enheduana.
lines.explanation: In this striking line, Enheduana's name, meaning 'high priestess, ornament of heaven,' is revealed, linking her identity to her sacred role.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’² ğ’€Š ğ’‰Œ ğ’… ğ’Š’ ğ’‚° ğ’‡² ğ’‰Œ ğ’…—
lines.translation: As I carried the basket, as I sang the hymns of joy,
lines.explanation: This line refers to a ritual basket used in temple offerings. The vowel symmetry between the two half-lines emphasizes the ritual action.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†  ğ’‹§ ğ’‚µ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’… ğ’ƒ» ğ’‚· ğ’‚Š ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’‹¾ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: funeral offerings were presentedâ€”did I no longer live there?
lines.explanation: The ki-si3-ga, or kispu in Akkadian, were offerings for the dead. The line hints at Enheduana's feeling of being metaphorically 'dead' or removed from life.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œ“ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’€ ğ’‹¼ ğ’Œ“ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’• ğ’‰‹
lines.translation: I came toward the lightâ€”the light burned me.
lines.explanation: The word u4 can mean both 'light' and 'tempest,' leading into the next line where shade becomes a storm. The symmetry of the line underscores the harsh transformation.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„‘ğ’ˆª ğ’‰ˆ ğ’€ ğ’‹¼ ğ’‡ ğ’‡» ğ’• ğ’… ğ’ˆ  ğ’Œ‹ğ’Œ†
lines.translation: I came toward the shadeâ€”it was covered in a storm.
lines.explanation: Here, the 'shade' is transformed into a storm, possibly indicating Enheduana's emotional turmoil or external challenges.

lines.translation: My honey mouth became froth,?
lines.explanation: This line describes Enheduana's loss of eloquence, possibly indicating a profound spiritual or emotional crisis.

lines.translation: My ability to sweeten moods is turned to dust.
lines.explanation: Enheduana's poetic and emotional powers have deteriorated, turning to 'dust'â€”a metaphor for something worthless or lost.

lines.translation: My fate, Suen, this Lugal-Ane:?
lines.explanation: The meaning of this line is ambiguous and opens the stanza directed at Suen (Nanna), Enheduana's father. The connection between Lugal-Ane and Enheduanaâ€™s fate suggests he might bring about her death.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’Š ğ’…— ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€Š ğ’€­ ğ’‰Œ ğ’„© ğ’ˆ  ğ’ƒ® ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: Tell An about it! May An resolve it for me!
lines.explanation: This line plays on the aural link between 'say' and 'unknot,' emphasizing that one would lead to the other. Enheduana asks Suen to intercede on her behalf with An.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€€ ğ’• ğ’‡´ ğ’€­ ğ’Š ğ’€ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€Š ğ’‰ ğ’€­ ğ’‚Š ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‚Š ğ’ƒ® ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: Tell An about it now, he will resolve it for us.
lines.explanation: An holds supreme moral authority, and Enheduana emphasizes the urgency of resolving the situation.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰† ğ’ˆ— ğ’€­ ğ’‰Œ ğ’Š© ğ’‚Š ğ’€ ğ’€Š ğ’‹¼ğ’€€ ğ’Š‘
lines.translation: The woman will tear off this fate, Lugal-Ane.?
lines.explanation: The 'woman' refers to Inana. Enheduana petitions Inana to remove the threat Lugal-Ane poses to her life, though interpretations vary.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†³ ğ’€€ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š’ ğ’„Š ğ’‰Œ ğ’‚  ğ’‰Œ ğ’ˆ¿
lines.translation: Mountains and floods lie at her feet.
lines.explanation: The imagery of mountains and floods at Inanaâ€™s feet highlights her overwhelming power.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š© ğ’‰ ğ’…” ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¤ ğ’Œ· ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’• ğ’€Š ğ’‡§ ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: The woman is mighty, she makes cities tremble before her.
lines.explanation: Inana's might causes entire cities to tremble, reinforcing her divine power.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’º ğ’€ ğ’Š® ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’„© ğ’ˆ  ğ’ˆ» ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: Stand by me! May her heartâ€™s contents be reconciled with me.
lines.explanation: This line expresses a plea for Inana's favor and emotional reconciliation, possibly directed at Suen or An.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚— ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ŒŒ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‚— ğ’€€ ğ’Š ğ’ª ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’…—
lines.translation: I am Enheduana. I will recite a prayer to you!
lines.explanation: As noted in l. 63, the word du11, 'speak,' must often be translated with different verbs in English, such as 'sing,' 'intonate,' or, as here, 'recite.' However one interprets the previous stanza, here Enheduana is clearly addressing Inana again.

lines.translation: My tears, which are like sweet beer,
lines.explanation: For the description of tears as 'sweet,' and more generally for why expressions of grief were thought to please the gods, see the discussion of ritual laments.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†¬ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¹ ğ’Š ğ’‹— ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‰Œ ğ’Š‘ ğ’‡ ğ’² ğ’ª ğ’‚µ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’…—

transliterations.simplified: ku Inanara Å¡u gamunirebar dizu gamurabdu

lines.translation: I will let flow free for you, holy Inana. I will say to you: 'The decision is yours!'
lines.explanation: This line introduces a metaphor that will become crucial to the poem as a whole: Enheduana describes her own situation as an unresolved court case, which Nanna has not settled, and which Enheduana therefore asks Inana to decide in his stead.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’€¸ ğ’½ ğ’Œ“ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’Š¨ ğ’…‡ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: I cannot make Dilimbabbar care.?
lines.explanation: Dilimbabbar is another name for Nanna; it can also be read as Ashimbabbar. The line is difficult to interpret, with various possible translations suggesting that Enheduana is either unable to make Nanna care about her situation or is telling Inana not to worry about him.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‹— ğ’ˆ› ğ’€­ ğ’†¬ ğ’‚µ ğ’†¤ ğ’ƒ» ğ’‰† ğ’ˆ  ğ’‰Œ ğ’‰Œ ğ’‰½

transliterations.simplified: Å¡uluh An kugake niÄ namani ikur

lines.translation: The rituals of holy An, all that belongs to him, have been disturbed,
lines.explanation: The Å¡uluh are purification rituals meant to cleanse priests and objects. Here, Enheduana laments that these sacred rituals have been disrupted, likely by Lugal-Ane's actions.

lines.translation: he has wrested the Eana from An:
lines.explanation: The Eana temple in Uruk, shared by An and Inana, has been taken by Lugal-Ane, an affront that directly affects both deities.

lines.translation: the greatest of the gods he does not fear.
lines.explanation: Lugal-Ane does not fear even the mightiest of gods, showing his brazen disregard for divine authority.

lines.translation: This temple, with whose charm he was not sated, whose delights he had not exhausted:
lines.explanation: The temple (literally 'house') is described as so enchanting that even its delights were not enough for Lugal-Ane.

lines.translation: this house he transformed into a house of evil.
lines.explanation: Lugal-Ane has turned what was once a sacred place into something malevolent, opposing An and Inana.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‹° ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’…† ğ’…” ğ’†­ ğ’Š ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’Š² ğ’ˆ  ğ’‰Œ ğ’„· ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‹¼
lines.translation: As he became equal to me, envy followed him.?
lines.explanation: This line can be interpreted in various ways. It seems to suggest that Lugal-Ane's actions were motivated by envy, which continues to follow him even as he usurps Enheduana's role.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’„¢ ğ’£ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’‡½ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’… ğ’Š¬ ğ’Š‘ ğ’‡½ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’… ğ’ˆª ğ’†ª ğ’‰

transliterations.transliteration: dsun2 zi-Äu10 lu2 he2-em-sar-re lu2 he2-em-mi-dab5-be2
transliterations.word_by_word: aurochs righteous-my man chase man seize

lines.translation: My righteous Aurochs! May you chase this man, may you seize him!
lines.explanation: The use of the divine determinative (the superscript 'd' before the first word) makes clear that 'sun2' is here used as an epithet of the goddess: '(Divine) Aurochs.'

lines.translation: In this life-giving landâ€”what am I?
lines.explanation: In her desperate situation, Enheduana asks where there is a place for her in the land of livingâ€”and if so, what that place is.

lines.translation: Like a rebel land hated by your Nanna: may An deliver it.
lines.explanation: The word translated as 'deliver,' 'Å¡um2,' here refers to passing something over to others. In this context, it would mean that An delivers it to destruction, giving it over so that it is no longer under divine protection.

lines.translation: This cityâ€”may An tear it to pieces,
lines.explanation: Note the balance of the half-lines, which have five syllables each and a symmetrical sequence of vowels: i-i-i-a-e / a-a-a-i-e.

lines.translation: may Enlil curse it.
lines.explanation: As in l. 18â€“19, Enlil appears alongside An, as the two main gods of the pantheon.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œ‰ ğ’€€ğ’…† ğ’…†ğ’Š’ ğ’• ğ’‰ ğ’‚¼ ğ’‰Œ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¹ğ’² ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: Its crying childrenâ€”may their mother not comfort them.
lines.explanation: The expression 'er2 pad3' may refer, not exactly to crying, but to the welling up of tears in oneâ€™s eyes.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’€€ ğ’‰ª ğ’†  ğ’ƒ» ğ’Š
lines.translation: Lady! When their grief has been set up,
lines.explanation: That is, when the city establishes the rituals of lamentation, in response to the destruction wrought upon by the gods.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„‘ ğ’ˆ£ ğ’€€ ğ’‰ª ğ’Š ğ’ª ğ’†  ğ’‰½ ğ’Š ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’… ğ’‹º
lines.translation: your boat of grief should be left in a foreign land.
lines.explanation: This couplet explicates the logic of ritual laments: when humans acknowledged the power of the gods through ostentatious grieving, the gods were expected to turn their destruction elsewhere.

lines.translation: Will I die because of my holy song?
lines.explanation: It is unclear what precisely this line refers to, but it might mean that Enheduana fears that she will be put to death because of her previous service as high priestess.

lines.translation: Me! My Nanna has not enquired about me.
lines.explanation: In other words, Nanna has not shown interest in her case. Instead of 'has not enquired,' one manuscript writes 'has not made a decision.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†  ğ’ˆœ ğ’†· ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’… ğ’„¢ ğ’„¢ ğ’‚Š
lines.translation: This false land has completely destroyed me.
lines.explanation: The word translated here as 'false,' lul, can also mean 'criminal' or 'renegade.' The expression recalls the earlier phrase ki zi-Å¡a3-Äal2-la, 'life-giving land.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’€¸ ğ’½ ğ’Œ“ ğ’‚Š ğ’² ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’€ ğ’Š ğ’‰ˆ ğ’…” ğ’…—
lines.translation: Dilimbabbar has not pronounced my verdict.
lines.explanation: For the name Dilimbabbar, see l. 84 above.

lines.translation: If he pronounced itâ€”what then? If he did not pronounce itâ€”what then?
lines.explanation: Dilimbabbarâ€™s verdict in the figurative court case no longer matters to Enheduana, either because it is too late (she is already on the verge of death), or because she has turned for support to Inana instead.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’…‡ ğ’ˆ  ğ’º ğ’º ğ’€ ğ’‚ ğ’‹« ğ’€ ğ’Š ğ’Œ“ğ’º
lines.translation: Standing victorious, he stepped out of the temple.
lines.explanation: The implicit subject of the line must again be Lugal-Ane. The word translated here as 'victorious' means more precisely 'having achieved oneâ€™s desires.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‹† ğ’„· ğ’¶ ğ’€Š ğ’‹« ğ’€ ğ’Š ğ’€­ ğ’Š‘ ğ’‚Š ğ’£ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’… ğ’ˆª ğ’…¥
lines.translation: Like a swallow, he made me fly through the windowâ€”my life has been devoured.
lines.explanation: Other manuscripts have instead 'he has devoured my life.'

lines.translation: Have you dispatched me to the thorns of foreign lands?
lines.explanation: Again, Attinger observes that the traditional reading of this lineâ€”'He has made me walk through the thorns of foreign lands'â€”is rendered improbable by the way the word is written. Instead, the line seems to be a question addressed to Inana.

lines.translation: He wrested the righteous crown of the high priestess from me,
lines.explanation: The phrase 'aga zi nam-en-na,' 'righteous crown of en-ship,' refers back to l. 4, where the same three words appear together. One manuscript has 'garment' instead of 'crown.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„ˆ ğ’€ ğ’• ğ’Š ğ’ˆ  ğ’€­ ğ’‹§ ğ’€€ ğ’Š ğ’€Š ğ’ŒŒ ğ’ˆ  ğ’€­ ğ’…—
lines.translation: he gave me a knife and dagger. â€œThey suit you,â€ he said.
lines.explanation: Lugal-Aneâ€™s taunting action can be interpreted in different ways. The suggestion may be that Enheduana should commit suicide, or that she will have to defend herself while in exile.

lines.translation: Precious lady, beloved by An!
lines.explanation: Once again, the word nin serves to mark the beginning of a new section. This fifth and penultimate section is framed by the three-fold repetition of the phrase 'lady, beloved by An.'

lines.translation: Your holy heart is mightyâ€”may it return to me!
lines.explanation: In the Sumerian idiom, the heart 'returning to its place' means a restoration of affection.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’‘ğ’® ğ’†  ğ’‰˜ ğ’€­ ğ’ƒ²ğ’” ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’…—
lines.translation: Beloved wife of Ushumgal-An,
lines.explanation: UÅ¡umgal-Anâ€”literally 'the basilisk of heaven'â€”is an epithet of Inanaâ€™s lover, Dumuzi.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’Œ« ğ’€­ ğ’‰º ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ƒ² ğ’‰ ğ’ˆ¨ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: You are the greatest lady from horizon to zenith.
lines.explanation: The words translated as 'horizon' and 'zenith' literally mean 'heaven-foundation,' an-ur2, and 'heaven-top,' an-pa.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’€€ ğ’‰£ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’†¤ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’„˜ ğ’„‘ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€­ ğ’ƒ» ğ’Š‘ ğ’Œ
lines.translation: The Anuna have submitted to you.
lines.explanation: This is the first of three lines in quick succession to begin with the name of the 'Anuna,' marking Inanaâ€™s superiority over the other gods of the pantheon.

lines.translation: From birth, you were a minor lady,
lines.explanation: Intriguingly, the line implies that Inana was not always held to be a major figure in the pantheonâ€”perhaps to explain why the goddess needs to be exalted.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’€€ ğ’‰£ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ƒ² ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ ğ’€€ ğ’¶ ğ’€ ğ’‚Š ğ’‰ˆ ğ’‹›ğ’€€ ğ’‚µ
lines.translation: But nowâ€”how you surpass the great Anuna gods!
lines.explanation: The Sumerian language is very sparing with conjunctions like 'and' or 'but,' so the words 'but now' are not there in the original, though the sentiment is clearly the same.

lines.translation: The Anuna kiss the ground for you.
lines.explanation: Literally, 'rub the place with their lips.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’² ğ’‰ ğ’‚· ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’Œ€ ğ’² ğ’‰½ ğ’² ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’¶ ğ’…† ğ’‚· ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’†¸ ğ’†¸

transliterations.transliteration: di ni2-Äa2 nu-mu-un-til di kur2 di-Äu10-gen7 igi-Äa2 mu-un-ni10-ni10
transliterations.word_by_word: case self-my not-complete case hostile case-my-like face-my encircle
transliterations.simplified: di niÄa numuntil di kur diÄugen igiÄa munnini

lines.translation: The trial against me is not over. A hostile verdict surrounds me, as if it were my verdict.
lines.explanation: As noted under l. 83, Enheduana interprets the ambiguity of her situation (exiled, but still alive) as an open court case: she feels a negative verdict looming toward her, but insists that the matter is not yet fully resolved, giving Inana time to intervene.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„‘ ğ’ˆ¿ ğ’„€ ğ’†¸ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’‹— ğ’‰¡ ğ’Œ ğ’ˆª ğ’‡²
lines.translation: I have not defiled? the flourishing? bed,
lines.explanation: It is unclear what this line refers to, in part because the expressions gi-rin-na, here translated 'flourishing,' and Å¡u_la2, here translated 'defile,' are unclear.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’…— ğ’…— ğ’‚µ ğ’€­ ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ƒ² ğ’‡½ ğ’Š ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’”
lines.translation: I have not revealed Ningalâ€™s speech to anyone,
lines.explanation: Again, the meaning of this line is unclear. As high priestess of Nanna, Enheduana would have had a special connection to Ningal.

lines.translation: I am the shining high priestess of Nanna.
lines.explanation: Though the previous two lines are unclear, it is possible to see them as averring that Enheduana has not betrayed her profession, meaning that she is still Nannaâ€™s legitimate priestess, even as she has been cast into exile.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’†  ğ’‰˜ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Š® ğ’ª ğ’„© ğ’ˆ  ğ’ˆ» ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: My lady, beloved by An, may your heart be reconciled with me!
lines.explanation: The phrase 'My lady, beloved by An,' introduces a new section: a final paean to Inanaâ€™s greatness.

transliterations.transliteration: he2-zu he2-zu-am3 dnanna li-bi2-in-du11-ga za-a-kam bi2-in-du11-ga
transliterations.word_by_word: know know Nanna not-speak yours speak
transliterations.simplified: hezu hezuam Nanna libinduga zakam binduga

lines.translation: May it be known, may it be known! Nanna has not spoken, so he has said: 'It is yours.'
lines.explanation: The line returns to the theme of the open court case, for which see l. 83 and 117: because Enheduanaâ€™s situation is ambiguous, Nanna must not have decided her case one way or the other, effectively leaving the matter to Inana.

lines.translation: That you are as mighty as heavenâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The following section enumerates Inanaâ€™s majestic traits, with each line ending in 'he2-zu-am3,' meaning 'may it be known.'

lines.translation: That you are as wide as the earthâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: It is a traditional trope in cuneiform literature to describe the gods as being as large as the earth and the heavens.

lines.translation: That you destroy the rebel landâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: From this line onward, the ancient manuscripts order the lines differently. This line emphasizes Inanaâ€™s power over rebellious lands.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’†³ ğ’Š ğ’…— ğ’Œ¤ ğ’‚Š ğ’ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ª ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That you roar against the enemy landâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: This line further emphasizes Inanaâ€™s power, describing her roar against enemy lands.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š• ğ’„‘ ğ’Š ğ’Š ğ’ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ª ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That you smash headsâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The phrase 'saÄ ÄiÅ¡ ra' is used to describe killing or smashing heads.

lines.translation: That you devour corpses like a lionâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The line likens Inana to a lion devouring corpses, emphasizing her fearsome nature.

lines.translation: That your eyes are furiousâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: In this context, 'eyes' likely refer to Inana's gaze, full of fury.

lines.translation: That you lift these furious eyesâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The line builds on the previous one, intensifying the imagery of Inanaâ€™s gaze.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’…† ğ’¯ ğ’¯ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ª ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That your eyes are iridescentâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The word 'gun3-gun3,' often applied to eyes, means 'shining, multi-colored, dappled, beautiful.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚— ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’‰¡ ğ’Šº ğ’‚µ ğ’ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ª ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That you are obstinate and defiantâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: The word 'nu-Å¡e-ga,' here translated as 'defiant,' literally means, 'one who does not obey.'

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’…‡ ğ’ˆ  ğ’º ğ’º ğ’ ğ’ ğ’ƒ¶ ğ’ª ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That you stand triumphantâ€”may it be known.
lines.explanation: Note the parallel to l. 104, where Lugal-Ane was said to stand triumphant, using the same expression.

lines.translation: Nanna has not spoken, so he has said: 'It is yours.'
lines.explanation: The line repeats the second part of l. 122.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œˆ ğ’„– ğ’…‹ ğ’‚— ğ’‰Œ ğ’ˆ¤ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: My lady, this has made you great, this has made you mighty.
lines.explanation: By letting Inana decide the case for him, Nanna has allowed Inana to become a ruler among gods, paving the way for her exalted position in the pantheon.

lines.translation: My lady, beloved by Anâ€”I will sing of your wrath.
lines.explanation: This is the third and final repetition of the phrase, 'My lady, beloved by An,' marking the beginning of the climactic section of the poem.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰ˆ ğ’„¯ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’¾ ğ’‹— ğ’ˆ› ğ’‹› ğ’‰ˆ ğ’…” ğ’²
lines.translation: I have piled up the coals, I have performed the ritual.
lines.explanation: The term Å¡uluh refers to purification rituals, performed without fault.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚  ğ’® ğ’†¬ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€­ ğ’…… ğ’Š® ğ’ª ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ˆ  ğ’ˆ» ğ’‰ˆ
lines.translation: The Holy Inn is ready for you. Will your heart not be reconciled with me?
lines.explanation: The Holy Inn refers to one of Inanaâ€™s cult centers, symbolizing readiness for her.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’… ğ’ˆ  ğ’‹› ğ’… ğ’ˆ  ğ’‹›ğ’€€ ğ’‚µ ğ’‹« ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’Œ¦ ğ’ƒ² ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’Œ…
lines.translation: As my heart was filled, overfilledâ€”lady, queenâ€”I gave birth to it for you.
lines.explanation: The narrator describes the production of the poem, with 'give birth' metaphorically referring to authorship.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’ƒ» ğ’ˆª ğ’…‡ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’ˆ  ğ’Š ğ’€­ ğ’…— ğ’‚µ ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: That which I sang to you at nighttime,
lines.explanation: The mention of the 'Äi6-u3-na,' or 'dead of night,' alludes back to earlier parts of the hymn. The connection suggests a contrast between Enheduana, who speaks eloquently to Inana, and the rebel woman who cannot.

lines.translation: may a gala repeat to you at midday.
lines.explanation: The gala is a type of priest, and here it suggests that the hymn or lamentation should be repeated at another time of day, emphasizing its importance.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’® ğ’†ª ğ’€ ğ’ ğ’†¤ ğ’Œ ğ’Œ‰ ğ’†ª ğ’€ ğ’ ğ’†¤ ğ’Œ
lines.translation: Because of your captive spouse, because of your captive child,
lines.explanation: The identities of the 'captive spouse' and 'captive child' are unclear. The line may be an allusion to ritual lamentations, adding a layer of complexity to the poem.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Œˆ ğ’€ ğ’ª ğ’Œˆ ğ’„– ğ’ŒŒ ğ’Š® ğ’ª ğ’‰¡ ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚— ğ’‹¼ ğ’‚—
lines.translation: your anger grows, your heart is not soothed.
lines.explanation: This line suggests that Inanaâ€™s anger is still strong, and her heart remains uncalmed. The tight construction of the line emphasizes the intensity of the emotion.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’„˜ ğ’Œ‡ ğ’‰ª ğ’…… ğ’„˜ ğ’‚— ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’†¤
lines.translation: The powerful lady, who is respected in the assembly,
lines.explanation: This line introduces the epilogue of the poem. The repeated sounds in each half-line reinforce the strength and authority of the lady (Inana).

lines.translation: received her prayer.
lines.explanation: Enheduana refers to herself in the third person, suggesting that the narrator is now the gala who repeated Enheduanaâ€™s hymn on the day after its composition. This grammatical shift marks a transformation from character to composer.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š® ğ’†¬ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¹ ğ’†  ğ’‰ ğ’€ ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€Š ğ’„„
lines.translation: Inanaâ€™s holy heart returned to her.
lines.explanation: The idiomatic expression of the heart returning to its place signals a restoration of affection, indicating that Inana is pleased with Enheduana's prayer.

transliterations.transliteration: u4 ba-an-na-du10 la-la ba-an-su3-su3 hi-li ma-az ba-an-du8-du8
transliterations.word_by_word: light be_pleasant charm spread delight lust release
transliterations.simplified: u banadu lala bansusu hili maz bandudu

lines.translation: The light pleased her: she was spreading charm, she was exuding passionate delight.
lines.explanation: This line contrasts the light here with the burning light mentioned earlier in the hymn, signaling a positive resolution of the crisis.

lines.translation: Like the moonlight shining forth, she was laden with charm.
lines.explanation: The reference to moonlight mirrors the beginning of the poem, creating a thematic closure.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’€­ ğ’‹€ğ’†  ğ’…†ğ’‚ ğ’£ ğ’‰ˆ ğ’Œ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’Œ¦ ğ’Œ“ğ’º
lines.translation: Nanna rightly expressed his admiration for her,
lines.explanation: Nanna's admiration reflects his approval of Inana, reinforcing the positive outcome of the prayer.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‚¼ ğ’‰Œ ğ’€­ ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ƒ² ğ’†· ğ’Š ğ’†ƒ ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€­ ğ’Š® ğ’€¸
lines.translation: she blessed her mother Ningal,
lines.explanation: In some manuscripts, Ningal blesses Inana instead, reflecting a positive resolution in their relationship.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’„‘ ğ’† ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’†¤ ğ’² ğ’ˆ  ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’ˆ¾ ğ’€Š ğ’‰
lines.translation: the doorframe said to her: â€œWelcome!â€
lines.explanation: The doorframe's greeting symbolizes the end of the hymn, marking the transition from ritual to the restored order.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’‰¡ ğ’ˆªğ’‰­ ğ’Š ğ’…— ğ’‚µ ğ’‰Œ ğ’ˆ¤ ğ’€€ğ’€­
lines.translation: Her speech to the nugig was mighty.
lines.explanation: This line's ambiguity, whether referring to Inana or Enheduana, symbolizes the mutual exaltation of the goddess and the priestess.

lines.translation: Destroyer of mountains, to whom the me were allotted by An,
lines.explanation: This phrase parallels earlier descriptions of Inanaâ€™s power, reaffirming her role as a cosmic force.

lines.sumerian_text: ğ’Š©ğ’Œ† ğ’ˆ¬ ğ’„­ ğ’‡· ğ’„˜ ğ’Œ“ğ’º ğ’€­ ğ’ˆ¹ ğ’  ğ’Š©

transliterations.simplified: ninÄu hili gu e Inana zami

lines.translation: My lady, wrapped in delight: Inana be praised!
lines.explanation: The final line of the poem follows the convention of ending with a phrase praising the deity, bringing the hymn to a ceremonious close.
